review_title: Very, Very Good -- But It Should Have Been Great! Blame the Director
review_detailed_main:
2006' "The Painted Veil" has so much going for it, it should have been another "English Patient" -- a retro romance that sweeps awards and captures hearts.

Instead we have that most frustrating creature -- a very, very good movie that just misses the mark of greatness.

Even so - if you like period romances, you may love what is lovable in this movie enough to forgive it its flaws.

What "The Painted Veil" has going for it:

1.) The plot of the Somerset Maughm novel. A nerdy, scientific, cuckolded husband, who knows his beautiful, shallow, society wife married him because she was dangerously close to being an old maid and wanted to get away from her mother, punishes her for an affair by taking her to a remote Chinese cholera epidemic. Yawza! How operatic!

2.) Sky-high production values. "The Painted Veil" was filmed on location in China. Locations were mixed and matched. At one point they were along the Li River, among Guilin's famous karst scenery. Karst is the "lumpy" looking limestone topography. Towers rise abruptly, and weirdly, out of river valleys, fringed by lush rice paddies and bamboo. The village Huang Yao is a five-hundred years old, intact Ming Dynasty town.

3.) Edward Norton is perfection. He gives Walter everything he needs -- as the nerdy, scientist cuckold husband, Walter is, by turns, arrogant, insecure, vengeful, loving, sweet, icy cold, naive, calculating ... you see it all on his face, and fear him, feel for him, and forgive him.

4.) Alexandre Desplat's award-winning score. Minimalist, and yet it conveys the plot's sense of entrapped passions and spiritual dimensions. Very good use is made of Eric Satie's Gnossienne # 1 and "A La Claire Fontaine," a French folksong whose bittersweet lyrics, which can be found on the web, are so appropriate to the plot that they are heartbreaking.

5.) Diminutive blond Toby Jones' depiction of Waddington, a British provincial officer who is just barely keeping up appearances, in his day old stubble, shabby, sweat-stained suits, and live-in Chinese lover, young enough to be his daughter. Jones pumps this small role full of life. In another actor's hands Waddington would have been forgettable; with Jones, he's one of the most interesting features of the movie.

6.) The Love / Sex / Death / Religion / Self-Sacrifice nexus that modern pop culture doesn't even seem to realize exists; any work of art that reminds us that what we love is mortal and that God and Sex live next door to each other in our brains / souls / lives is way ahead of the pack.

7.) A scene from a Chinese opera. A vermilion and turquoise costume. Lin Zheng's brilliant performance.

8.) Anthony Wong as Colonel Yu. Again, a minor part, but Wong is riveting.

What I wish had been different: 1.) Liev Schreiber has an unmistakable earnestness that just doesn't work for him to be believable as a rack, cad, and bounder. He was much better as the earnest, befuddled cuckold in "Walk on the Moon."

2.) Naomi Watts. She's very pretty and very sweet and I just never, ever believed her as a shallow, devastatingly beautiful socialite who could drive two men to irresponsible action.

I kept thinking of Greta Garbo in the original "Painted Veil," or Vivien Leigh as that insufferable monster, Scarlett -- as much as you hate her, you are fascinated. Not so with Watts.

3.) John Curran's direction. This is a MELODRAMA, John. Walter says, "I despise myself for loving you." Kitty says, "If a man doesn't have what it takes to make a woman love him, that's his fault." I mean, how can you direct that so anemically? As if they are asking for change to buy cheez crackers from the vending machine? In melodrama, you have to turn up the heat, send a few lightening bolts across the screen.

4.) The ending. I didn't need a happy or a sad ending. I just needed an ending that would serve the plot, and feel less like a dead end, a flat tire, that drained, rather than contributed, meaning to what has come before.

review_title: Ponderous and predictable, gloomy "romance" with lush scenery and some strong performances
review_detailed_main:
"The Painted Veil" is a film based on W. Somerset Maugham's 1925 novel of the same name. The story is of an upper class, independent-minded woman, Kitty (Naomi Watts), in mid-1920s England. Her family is anxious to marry her off, and she quickly finds herself as the wife of infectious disease researcher Dr. Walter Fane (Edward Norton). He takes her to his work in Shanghai and then to the remote village Mei-tan-fu in the Southern Chinese province of Guangxi, where he has volunteered to help to combat a deadly cholera epidemic.

The story is one of marriage to a man so focused on his work that he only speaks when something needs to be said, a passionless relationship that formulaically leads to extra-marital passion. Almost as penance, Walter announces that they are going to a place that Kitty feels no (English) woman belongs, without consulting Kitty and with no regard to her interests or well-being. The stark choice for her is to face shameful divorce or join in; when Charlie Townsend (Liev Schreiber) all too predictably declines to leave his wife and marry his love, Kitty, there seems to be no choice at all.

Despite some strong performances, particularly by Naomi Watts, Dame Diana Rigg in the film as the vivacious Mother Superior in charge of an orphanage, gorgeous scenery, and expectations to enjoy what I thought would be a romantic period film like many others that I have relished (such as Merchant Ivory Productions' 1992 "Howards End" or 1985 "A Room with a View"), I had serious reservations about "The Painted Veil". I thought that the story was rather ponderous and predictable with flawed character development.

I found unrealistic Walter's cold detachment and irresponsibility to not even inoculate his wife. Much as Kitty's character is developed reasonably well, she bears the cross of her predicament in a manner that doesn't seem consistent with her pre-marital characterization. Her somehow uncrushed spirit and the scenes in the orphanage provided much needed respite from the stern, closed Walter.

The couple's relationship, initially of course a societally imposed one, grew into one that never made sense to me. Walter's almost total self-absorption and lack of sensitivity (such as initially banning all of the villager's sources of water without considering how they would drink - not much of a boon to the community or a cogent public health approach) further hardened and distanced his characterization. In fact, with few exceptions (such as eccentric neighbor Waddington played by Toby Jones), many of the other characters were, to me, relatively flat.

Clearly on the personal level there was Walter's patronizing and very unfriendly demeanor, but there was otherwise little plot development about anti-colonialistic resentment of the Chinese toward the English. The more pernicious colonial impact the British had on India seems to be much better known than the Opium Wars and colonial influence in China in the 19th and early 20th centuries, and the film could have encouraged a little curiosity by revealing a bit more historical fiction rather than relying on some unspecified fears. Ann Hu's 2000 film "Shadow Magic" is but one example that I am reminded of that weaves a much richer background tapestry.

On the other hand, the scenery was magnificently shot in soft, lush scenes that provided an interesting contrast to the harsh story. Waddington and Mother Superior offer clever dialogue; it was charming, for example, to hear the nun reflect, "I fell in love when I was seventeen {pause} with God. A foolish girl with romantic notions . But my love was passionate. Over the years, my feelings have changed. He's disappointed me, ignored me. We've settled into a relationship of peaceful indifference. The old husband and wife who sit side by side on the sofa but rarely speak. He knows I will never leave him, this is my duty. But when love and duty are one, then grace is within you."

I liked the costumes, music, and flow of the film, with powerful nonlinearities reinforcing Kitty's entrapment. Walter's eventual understanding that aiding others suggests not a condescending but a compassionate sense of working together, may offer a gentle reminder of some relevance in contemporary society, whether in regard to diplomacy, warfare, or dealing with still current issues of poverty and disease. In a very real sense, the film itself offers promise as, I believe, the first film co-produced between the Chinese government and a Western studio.

I often enjoy romantic historical fiction and, based on other reviews that I have seen (and some awards, such as a Golden Globe for Best Original Score), expect some other enthusiasts of the genre (if indeed this film can be called "romantic") to find more merit in "The Painted Veil" than I did. I do recommend for those that those who want to see it to experience it while it is on the big screen; the impact of the mountains, rice fields, water, and crowds need to be appreciated in the large.

6 stars out of 10

Painted Veil is an enjoyable adaption of a Somerset Maugham novel. It's about a British couple and their marital troubles and it's set in China in 1925. Britain is the colonial power and there is tension with the locals. Walter Fane (Edward Norton) is a nerdy MD who runs a medical facility in Shanghai. On a trip back to London he falls in love with Kitty Koerber (Naomi Watts) after meeting her at party. He proposes and she accepts, although she doesn't love him.

Kitty is a frivolous and spoiled socialite and she quickly becomes bored with expat life. She has an affair with a married diplomat Charlie Townsend (Liev Schreiber). Walter finds out and threatens to reveal their adultery and divorce Kitty if she doesn't help him treat a cholera epidemic in the hinterland. Kitty slowly develops a social conscience and helps the nuns at a local orphanage. She grows to love Walter as he tends the sick and dying. Walter had planned the trip to punish Kitty but he gradually forgives her. Toby Jones plays a friendly but decadent local British official who enjoys opium and the charms of his Chinesse mistress.

The film is about grown-up relationships and the characters are complex and articulate. The acting is excellent, although Watts is a little old to play the ingénue.

review_title: If you thought the David Lean tradition in movies was gone, I tell you it is not!
review_detailed_main: Walter (Edward Norton) is an English doctor and bacteriologist who has chosen to try and help improve conditions in China. On leave in London, he wants to find a wife and casts his eye on pretty Kitty (Naomi Watts). Kitty is a spoiled society girl who resists Walter's overtures, at first. Nevertheless, when she hears her mother complaining about her to friends, Kitty decides to marry the doctor. Bliss does not follow. Walter is a gentleman who has difficulty expressing his feelings and is very absorbed in his work, too. Young and foolish, Kitty finds affection in the arms of another man named Charlie (Liev Schrieber). But, when Walter finds out about the fling, he gives Kitty an ultimatum. Go with him to the interior of China to aid in a cholera epidemic or face disgrace. For various reasons, they make the trip but they are still seething with resentment towards each other. Can anything good come out of this situation? This is a movie in the grand tradition of David Lean or Merchant and Ivory. The story, based on a Somerset Maugham novel, is first rate, with characters most interesting and complex. All of the actors do a great job, with Norton and Watts giving excellent performances as two very difficult people who learn how to truly love their fellow human beings. As for the China setting, it is exotic and breaktakingly beautiful and the cinematography captures it very well. Compliments should also be extended to the costumes and overall production values. The only drawback for some viewers may be the slow pace and the lack of slam-bam action. This is primarily a movie of character study and that, sometimes, requires patience. For those who stay with the film, however, the rewards are tenfold and more. It is a most beautiful movie, in every way, and one which most viewers will want to see many, many times over the coming years.

Somerset Maugham has written a story about a British couple who go to China during the midst of the Cholera epidemic and during turbulent political time. The couple, Dr. Walter Fane, played fine by Edward Norton and his wife played by Naomi Watts. Her character is particularly troubling. She is quite promiscuous and unfaithful to her husband with Liev. Schreiber's character. Her husband Dr. Walter Fane is a bacteriologist during the cholera epidemic and needed in a remote region in China. After their marriage, he falls madly in love with her and she marries him to escape her parents. I found Norton's Walter to be cold and cruel at times to her. I found Watts to be captivating and complicated at the same time. Dame Diana Rigg has a supporting role as a Mother Superior in an orphanage. Toby Jones was wonderful in playing Waddington. I just found him to be compelling and worth watching. The cast is first rate. The story is a bit uneven at times. In the end, I felt cheated. Despite the beauty of China in this film, the film's script needed more to keep it going. I enjoyed it though but mostly because I found Watts and Jones to be the outstanding roles in the film and of course, Dame Diana Rigg, too.

As a novelist, Somerset Maugham (1874-1965) might have been, as he said himself, "in the very front row of the second rate", but he told a good story. The film-makers here have altered Maugham's story somewhat but they have not lost track of its essentials  a marriage based on superficial attraction on the part of the husband (Walter) and a desire to get away from her family on the part of the wife (Kitty) matures into a real love-match under adverse conditions. This is despite Kitty having being brought up to be a vacuous socialite and Walter being emotionally repressed and very controlling.

As befits a period piece the film has an old-fashioned look about it (except for the opening montage), but good cinematographic use is made of the Karst landscape around Guilin in Guangxi province and the performances are almost faultless. The Chinese people themselves, in the middle of both a cholera epidemic and a civil war, are given more prominence than Maugham gave them. This is welcome and does not detract from the central story.

Naomi Watts is a fine feckless and then fighting Kitty (a tough class  Garbo played her in the 1934 version) and Edward Norton gets Walter, the man of science overtaken by emotion just right, though at times I wondered whether another very uptight character he has played, Derek Vinyard of "American History X" was seeping through. Liev Schreiber did not have a lot to do as Kitty's faithless lover but he did it well. Tony Jones was very good as the backwoods colonial official Waddington, who, like many of his ilk had 'gone native' but had not lost his manners. Anthony Wong gave a rounded performance as Colonel Yu, the local Kuomintang army commander. I chuckled to see Diana Rigg as a French nun with a very British accent, but she had some of the best lines.

I'm pleased to see this film did well in its first week of its much delayed Australian release (it took over $600,000, according to "The Australian" of 30 April 2008). And why not? Here is a good story well filmed with interesting characters well portrayed set in an exotic locale (for us Westerners at least). Perhaps a little dated and with most appeal to an older audience, but plenty of us will still stagger out to the movies to see a sound piece of film-making like this.

I did enjoy this melodrams set in mid 20's China, even if the story of missionary workers striving to help the needy is hardly an original one in the cinema.

What spices this tale up however are the motivations of the husband and wife characters played by Edward Norton and Naomi Watts, he the socially inept, earnest scientist cuckold, she his flighty, rebellious and beautiful young wife who marries him to escape her restricted home life and is soon having a torrid affair with a married man. review_title: Love and redemption in a time of cholera
review_detailed_main:
"The Painted Veil" (2006) was directed by John Curran and adapted from a novel by W. Somerset Maugham. The movie is set in China in the 1920's, during an outbreak of cholera. Naomi Watts plays Kitty Fane, a beautiful and spoiled young woman who marries her physician husband basically for want of something better to do.

Dr. Fane (Edward Norton) works in a British government medical laboratory in Shanghai, and volunteers to travel to the area of the cholera outbreak, although he's a scientist, not a clinician. This assignment is doubly dangerous, because the area is only partially under control of the regular Chinese army. Power is shared with the local war lord. All the Chinese resent the foreigners, even those--like Dr. Fane--who are trying to help them.

The plot revolves around the relationship between the Fanes as they confront this dangerous, unstable situation. Although both Watts and Norton are excellent, I thought the acting honors were earned by Toby Jones, who plays Waddington, the English official assigned to the area. Waddington has seen it all and done it all, and he's obviously stuck in this remote region because he doesn't really fit in with the Shanghai diplomatic elite.

This movie is about love, betrayal, and redemption. The acting is strong, the scenery is breathtaking, and the conclusion is dramatic but believable. It's not a film you'll easily forget.

P.S. Diana Rigg (yes, that Diana Rigg) plays the old Mother Superior of a convent and orphanage in the region. I've never known a Mother Superior, so someone will have to tell me whether they are always as portrayed in the movies--intensely spiritual and yet pragmatic and wise in the ways of the world.

review_title: A "Brief Encounter" for a New Generation
review_detailed_main:
This simply gorgeous and scandalously overlooked 2006 release manages to be a sweeping old-fashioned Hollywood romance while completely avoiding the righteous bombast that usually makes movies like this so intolerable.

Based on a novel by W. Somerset Maugham (and apparently filmed at least once before with Greta Garbo in the starring role), this film tells the story of a young and impetuous English lady (Naomi Watts) who rashly decides to marry a stuffy bacteriologist (Edward Norton) to escape the displeasure of her family and the danger of turning into a spinster. The two move to China, where the doctor pursues his work and the young woman becomes increasingly bored. She begins an affair with a swaggering compatriot (Liev Shreiber), and when her husband catches her at her game, he decides to punish her by volunteering his aid to a cholera epidemic that is ravaging a remote village, and drags her along with him. Once there, and in the face of something vastly larger than either of them, the two begin to realize how petty their marital squabbling is, and each begins to see the good in the other that up to that point was hidden entirely by the bad. The love that develops between them is not the phony, hyperbolic, passionate love that Hollywood aggressively tries to convince us exists, but rather the much more realistic love that is based on mutual admiration and respect.

The characters played by Watts and Norton are fascinating, and the two actors do an amazing job inhabiting them. This project was obviously their baby, as both served as producers, and their passion for it shows. They also happen to have a great deal of screen chemistry together. The film is superbly intelligent and unsentimental, and God love it for that. My wife and I found out after watching it together that both of us separately and without knowing it were reminded of "Brief Encounter," one of our favorite movies. It's not like that 1946 masterpiece in terms of plot, but it's very much like it in terms of tone and in its attitudes about love and relationships. Both films are frank and candid about the many flaws human beings bring to their interactions with other human beings, and both honestly address the distinction between love and lust and don't try to pretend that they always go together.

On top of all that, the film looks spectacular. It's the kind of period drama that the Academy usually wets itself over, so I can't imagine how it was overlooked in categories like art direction, cinematography and costume design. But perhaps the fact that the Academy completely ignored it is the highest endorsement I can make for it.

Grade: A

review_title: A beautiful and enjoyable old-fashioned love story.
review_detailed_main:
The Painted Veil is a an American-Chinese co-production based on the eponymous novel by A. W. Somerset Maugham. It is also a remake of the same-titled film filmed in 1934 starring Greta Garbo, and The Seventh Sin filmed in 1957 with Eleanor Parker. The movie tells the troubled relationship of a couple of newly-weds: Kitty Fane, a shallow middle-class girl who marry for practical reasons and without love, and her husband Walter Carwin, a fine epidemiologist going to China to fight an outbreak of cholera, who falls in love with Kitty at first sight.

The movie goes beyond the usual romance story or period movie, and has a good insight into the historical events occurring in China in the 1920s, but also into the differences between infatuation and true love, which is the focus of the film. This is a story about human connection in a broad level: Connection between different cultures (in this case the British and the Chinese, and how Colonialism affected them) and connection at an intimate level, both with your inner self (seeing a facet of your own personality that you did not know existed), and with another person (husband and wife).

The movie was filmed completely on location and has a an authenticity to it that is difficult to find nowadays, when most movies are set in a country and filmed in a completely different one. The historical setting, the costumes, and the music create a wonderful atmosphere, very similar to the one old movies used to have. The music by Alexandre Desplat and the cinematography by Stuart Dryburgh are simply magnificent.

Regarding the acting, I initially thought that the leading couple of Naomi Watts (Kitty)-Edward Norton (Walter) weren't suited as the leading couple, but, after watching the movie, I think think they are, although Norton outshines Watts by far despite this being a role out of his comfort zone. The story would have lost authenticity if the leading actor was a super-handsome glamorous actor, which is not what men were at the time; Norton convincingly portrays the logical man of the time, right in his manners, rational, a foolish romantic, a man of honor, and not very expressive emotionally. Naomi Watts is OK in her performance, but somewhat I couldn't believe she was a woman of the 1920s in her looks, body language or performance; in fact she doesn't have any chemistry on camera with her real life husband Liev Schreiber (who plays diplomat Charlie Townsend). Toby James is very good as the sensitive and common sensed Waddington, as well as Diana Rigg as the very human Mother superior, and Anthony Wong Chau-Sang as Colonel Yu. Schreiber is just correct in his portray of Charlie, whose character is just a mere catalyst in the story. The rest of the cast is good in their respective roles.

A beautiful and enjoyable old-fashioned love story.

review_title: Classic story of a woman's spiritual metamorphosis acted with precision.
review_detailed_main: I love literary film adaptations and W.Somerset Maugham was a brilliant writer of his age. He centres on the former Colonial world of Britain in outlandish places. The film script kept to his minimalist tradition; good plot, clean-cut dialog, authentic characterizations, interesting locations and cultures. Where it failed was that there was no noticeable progression of feeling between the two main characters. A non-involved observer is not aware of the depths of jealousy and passion that lurk beneath the surface of Kitty and Walter. Edward Norton adopted an excellent English accent and I found his acting style appropriate to the piece. I wonder if the fact that Liev Schreiber, (Naomi Watt's husband playing her love interest in the film) inhibited a significant development between the Watts' and Norton's characters?

review_title: A Romance Strangely Lacking In Passion Of Any Kind
review_detailed_main:
Others may well disagree, but what I found most disappointing about this movie was the lack of any obvious passion - strange for a movie that depicts itself as a romance. The movie essentially narrates the origins and development of the relationship between Dr. Walter Fane (Edward Norton) and Kitty (Naomi Watts), who becomes his wife, and yet for the most part the Fanes don't seem to possess either blinding love or boiling hatred - mutual disinterest and contempt might be the best way to describe most of their time together.

Essentially, Fane takes Kitty to Shanghai where he works as an infectious disease researcher. He largely ignores her, and after discovering that she's having an affair with a local British diplomat, he packs them both off to a small, remote village suffering from a cholera epidemic. The relationship evolves in this village.

Frankly, this is neither a bad movie nor a great one. It's quite slow-paced and lacking in passion as I've noted above. It also provides an interesting look at the effects of cholera. Having visited a rural (and less remote) area of China as recently as 2005, I have to say that I thought the conditions in the remote village portrayed here (cholera notwithstanding) seemed too good - I'm thinking here of the state of repair of the buildings.

Anyway, this gets a 4/10 from me for a decent enough ending to a somewhat uninspiring movie.

review_title: Edward Norton a total change from bad boy
review_detailed_main: I love this movie. It is one of my favorite movies I will get no tired watching it again and again. I have hated and fallen in love with Walter Fane, same as Kitty did. Edward Norton played that character simply perfect. Each simple detail on the way he moved, walked, watched, breathed added the right value/element to the character and transmitted plenty of emotions. Naomi Watts!!! Oh another excellent actor to this movie. I hated the frivolous Kitty at first, but than I hated Walter for "making it pay" to well matured Kitty later. Excellent movie in every single detail.

Set first in Shanghai then in a cholera-filled village deep in the heart of China in the early 1920s. A young woman marries a stiff, upright doctor simply to get away from her nagging family and then has an affair with a womanizing friend of her husband. Sparing the details, they both end up traveling to the village plagued by cholera and ultimately learn something about marriage and love. This is pure melodrama and it drags a bit at times, but the acting is great with Watts looking stunning and perfectly portraying the bored and sensual wife. Edward Norton, one of the best actors of the decade, gives a performance that is almost too stiff at times, but still is pretty convincing as a British doctor despite the corny accent. The directing is smooth and consistent, the cinematography gorgeously shows the wonders of China, and the ending is something to be remembered. Overall, this is a beautiful period piece that reminded me very much of the old classic love stories. There are a lot of problems here, but you know they will be worked out.

Slightly stilted and precious, but still mildly intriguing literary adaptation that strives for accuracy and succeeds, at least, on the visual level.

The storyline is another matter, as all the initial events are played out too broadly while the pic's reconciliatory main bulk may be more interesting, but goes on for too long.

The actors are fine and compared to all the execrable Hollywood romances, this tasteful concoction offers honest glimpses into the human condition called love.

review_title: A compelling drama with some obvious plot points.
review_detailed_main:
I am usually not a fan of romantic drama's but the dark twist and setting of this movie made me throughly enjoy it.

The plot: A young doctor (Edward Norton) enters an emotionless marriage with rich, rather spoiled woman(Naomi Watts) and struggles through his relationship, whilst aiding a Chinese village plagued by cholera.

The writing: Is good and contains a lot of symbolism that could be more subtle. The village they are in symbolized their relationship and its condition changes accordingly. This was done very cleverly and allowed the scenario Norton and Watts to coincide with their relationship. The script itself has some schmaltzy moments but it did endear me to the characters. The conversations between to the two main leads felt natural and none of the lines are ham fisted. The final act (though not as powerful as other dramas ala The Pianist)was effective to make me feel sympathetic to the characters in the movie, due to the atrocities they have experienced. The balance between the plague and the emotional turmoil experienced by the main leads is amazing, and allows the movie to have some spectacularly dark and jubilant scenes.

The acting: Norton and Watts do a solid performance that is both believable and enjoyable. I truly felt the happiness, hatred, and love they emoted at the camera. However I thought the Asian side characters where quite weak ,and could have been developed more, being only there to die or provide Asiatic stereotypes. Toby Jones is also to be commended for his great performance as an English ambassador.

The cinematography: The movie used a lot of soft lighting to the audience bringing out the emotive faces of the actors. There was a nice balance between close up shots of the two leads ,and medium shots to illustrate the plagued state of the village.There were also some beautiful and bleak long shots of the Chinese country side and the village.

The soundtrack: Great using oriental music to fit in with the background, and a more string heavy track for the more distressing scenes. There is also some classical piano songs (Watts character plays the piano) that fits in well with the more western areas of the town (the church/orphanage), and scenes shot in a western district.

Criticism: I thought the ending was quite cliché albeit executed perfectly. There were some scenes developing Watts character that were kind of dull (involving the church, and her being bored), and i thought those could have been used to develop Norton's character more (who seemed much more nuance).

This movie definitely deserves a rent and can be quite heart wrenching given the right circumstances.

7.6/10

review_title: Classic films should be remade now and then, if for no other reason than to remind us of what true literature is all about.
review_detailed_main:
Classic films should be remade now and then, if for no other reason than to remind us of what true literature is all about. The Painted Veil is one of those incredibly compelling films which deals directly with the human condition, specifically under conditions which warrant reaction. Edward Norton, Naomi Watts, and Liev Schreiber create an ensemble fitting of a Maugham novel, and their performances are flawless.

Flawless as well is the cinematography and photography in this wonderful adaptation of the novel. Filmed entirely in China, the scenery is breathtaking and lends to the authenticity of the film. This also enhances the "illusion of the first time" which is so critical in any film, since the novel is set in China. A huge cast of extras is included.

The Painted Veil is a film which may not be suitable for the entire family (Rated PG-13 for some scenes of sexuality, partial nudity, disturbing images and brief drug content), but I don't believe it will offend older children, and I know it will entertain anyone who likes a well-acted film.

It's 1925 China. Kitty (Naomi Watts) and her dull husband Dr. Walter Fane (Edward Norton) are traveling into the interiors for him to study infectious diseases. In flashbacks, their marital troubles are revealed. Kitty found him lackluster at first but her mother threatened to cut her off. In China, she had an affair with the dashing married diplomat Charlie Townsend (Liev Schreiber). She wanted a divorce and run off with Charlie but Charlie won't get a divorce himself. The question is if the couple can reconnect in the Chinese wilderness in revolutionary times. The only neighbors are the Deputy Commissioner Waddington (Toby Jones) and his Chinese woman. A guard is assigned to her as foreigners face threats.

This is not the sappy romance as one would expect. It is darker than at first glanced. Walter doesn't start in the best light and neither does Kitty. Their reconciliation is something slowly earned. The major drawback is that the couple needs more time together and the movie is a bit too long. Cholera is not necessarily the most sexy thing and she has no good way to get into that part of the story.

The Painted Veil has it all going for itself. Naomi Watts and Edward Norton leading, two great actors. An interesting theme and issue, Cholera in China in 1920 and a great location to tease beauty from, but none of this is taken to its advantage.

Director John Curran shoots this self-named political romance in a way where it's so trying to be unique, that it turns out to be not so. Curran seems to refuse to even attempt at pulling away from the dreary, wooden lifestyle of the early 1900's that is so majorly presented in other films, and therefore throughout the film seems to sort of descend into not even trying to be unique anymore.

Having not much earlier experience or success, Curran seems to have jumped at the opportunity of a movie about a politically buckling country, after seeing the Oscar success those types of films have had recently. Namely, The Last King of Scotland and Blood Diamond. In all the excitement however, Curran seems to have forgotten that to have winning political films like them, the films have to be good.

But, I shouldn't rant on about John Curran when the obvious major culprit is the screenwriter. Ron Nyswaner tries but fails at creating thought provoking and understated dialogue and story. It's heartbreaking when you can tell he has obviously tried at making it these things when it just turns out to look flimsy and thin under the influence of such a promising cast. Edward Norton strives to get something out of his sketchy and single-mooded character but again, fails, just like the rest of the crew on this film.

However, there are moments of genuine flair, but this only occurs in obvious exciting bits, which makes you think the Director only chose to do the film for these sequences. Long half hour dull patches are injected with 1 minute scored sequences of someone dying of cholera and the disgust on Edward Norton's face, and despite these only being the good bits because, finally, there's something interesting to watch, you do feel that there may be a tiny bit of promise for the rest of the film, but guess whatthe score stops, Norton stops looking disgusted, and we cut to Naomi Watts, sitting in a chair sighing again.

The writer seems to have run out of ink only when he had established 2 plot lines, a novelty guard, and the idea that making the characters British makes them deep in itself.

Somehow, however, this film drags these 2 plot lines, the guard and the British accents along with it for the whole 2 and a bit hours, to solidify the fact that Naomi Watts isn't as good as everyone says, that just because movies are about redemption and political issues with foreigners, it doesn't make them good, and that The Painted Veil, overall, is a thin, and boring movie.

review_title: Exotic British romantic tragedy in cholera-plagued revolutionary China

review_detailed_main:
"The Painted Veil" is an American excursion into the traditionally British territory of "heritage cinema", although much of the story is set in China and it is based upon a novel by a British writer, W. Somerset Maugham. It is essentially a study of a dysfunctional marriage. The two parties to that marriage are very different in personality. Walter Fane is a shy, socially awkward doctor, working as a bacteriologist for the Chinese government. While on leave in London, he meets and falls in love with Kitty Garstin, a shallow and empty-headed young socialite. Although she is not in love with him, she is flattered by his attentions and marries him at the urging of her domineering mother. Following the marriage, the couple go to live in Shanghai, where Walter works in a laboratory.

The marriage is not a success and Kitty is bored by her husband, who seems dull and unable to respond to her emotionally. She begins an affair with Charles Townsend, the British vice-consul. When Walter discovers her infidelity, he threatens to divorce her for adultery unless she agrees to accompany him to a remote area of China where a cholera epidemic is raging and where he has volunteered his services. When Townsend refuses her request that he should leave his wife and marry her, Kitty is left feeling that she has no choice but to accept Walter's ultimatum. During the first half of the twentieth century- the story is set in 1925- there was a curious social convention that it was morally worse for a wife to cheat on her husband than vice versa. Maugham clearly felt that, for some women at least, the risk of dying from cholera was preferable to the stigma of being named as the guilty party in a divorce case.

"Heaven hath no rage like love to hatred turned" wrote Congreve in "The Mourning Bride", and this is Walter's motivation for dragging his wife on a long, arduous and dangerous journey; his love for her has turned to hatred and he is determined to punish her for her affair with Townsend. Yet, unlike Congreve, Maugham clearly believed that hatred could turn back into love. Upon their arrival in Mei-tan-fu, where they live in squalid accommodation, Walter and Kitty barely speak to each other. Yet under the strain of their difficult circumstances, they begin to discover good qualities in one another. Kitty, who once saw Walter as dull and emotionally cold, now begins to appreciate him for his courage, determination and selflessness. Perhaps more surprisingly, he also begins to see good qualities in Kitty, whom he had previously regarded as shallow and selfish.

Director John Curran said that he wanted the movie to look distinctly Chinese, and to this end it was shot on location in a mountainous area of China; the village we see is real, not a set. Curran's purism must have added to the cost of shooting the film, but I think that it is justified, for two reasons. The first is that, visually, this is a strikingly attractive film. The second is that the film is not just the story of Walter and Kitty's marriage, but is also about China itself. In a way, it is a film about colonialism, but not about the direct political variety, unlike Maugham's novel which was set in the British colony of Hong Kong. The colonialism we see here is of the intellectual and cultural variety, the assumption on the part of Westerners, even many who opposed political colonialism, that ideas originating in Europe or North America were automatically superior to those originating in other parts of the world. Although the film-makers were too tactful to draw direct parallels, Communism can be seen as the ultimate expression of this intellectual colonialism. Many of the disasters which afflicted China in the mid twentieth century, such as the Great Famine and the Cultural Revolution were the result of Mao's attempt to shoehorn China into the framework of a nineteenth-century ideology devised by a German sitting in the British Museum and first put into practice in Russia.

Edward Norton, who plays Walter, described his character as "the proxy for the arrogance of Western rationalism". Despite Walter's heroism and selflessness, he brings to his relationships with the Chinese something of the cold rationality he originally brought to his marriage, which means that his efforts are not always appreciated. His performance in this film strengthened my view, derived from films like "Primal Fear", "American History X" and "Kingdom of Heaven" that Norton is one of the most intelligent and thoughtful actors currently working in Hollywood. It always surprises me that he has never won an Oscar. His British accent is pretty good too.

The other performance that stood out for me was from Diana Rigg as the Mother Superior of a local orphanage run by French nuns; Naomi Watts as Kitty and Liev Schreiber as Charles were adequate but not outstanding. The film is at times too slow-moving, but overall it is a well-crafted piece of storytelling. 7/10

Oh my! During one of my insomniac episodes, while perusing HBO in the middle of the night, I came across this movie, about half way into it. I have always loved Naomi Watts and was interested to see that she was sporting a brunette hair color. Anyway, a few minutes into the film, I realized it was a "period piece". After having seen atonement this year, I was prepared to jump into this movie even at the halfway mark. Having to go on the dialog to try to figure out why Ed Norton was so hateful to her, made me realize that I was going to have to see the film from the beginning. I decided to stick it out and the cinematography alone was worth watching a movie half way in. I was able to derive from comments that Kitty had been unfaithful, and that she was paying for it. I was able to watch the movie again later that day and was completely enraptured by the scenery, the story and the characters. The acting is superb, believable and the story is wonderfully scripted. I love the idea that even though they started out so sadly, that there was redemption and love in the end. I think this movie was highly overlooked in the awards arena.

Terrific Movie about terrific subjects: Infidelity and dealing with it is one topic. Here it is handled according to the rules of the 1920ies which don't apply to us anymore (but could be considered, just in case to prevent lawyers from getting fat over divorces). Bringing hygiene standards to uneducated masses against traditions is the other. We are facing H1N1 and Ebola and the problems still seem the same. Great performances by Naomi Watts, Edward Norton and Toby Jones (I preferred Diana Riggs mocking glimpses in The Avengers to her sweet loving glances as Mother Superior), but if you would have cut down the scenes of Dr. Fanes self- righteousness to what was really needed, you could have saved half an hour of film.

We found a DVD in our holiday apartment and decided to watch it one evening. Edward Norton , Naomi Watts and Toby Jones are just marvellous in this period piece. It is set in China and is exquisitely shot bringing to life the landscape as we see in old prints and the like. It is delightful and harrowing by turns and it makes the viewer become involved in the main characters lives in a way that few films manage. It is a film about a passionate love, infidelity, forgiveness and reconciliation set against a virulent cholera epidemic. The premise does not sound promising but The Painted Veil delivers on all fronts. Highly recommended.

"We humans are more complex than your silly little microbes. We're unpredictable. We make mistakes and we disappoint."

Set primarily in China during a cholera outbreak in 1925, The Painted Veil is about a bacteriologist that intentionally takes his young wife to a cholera-stricken village in order to punish her for her infidelity. The couple seems unsuited for each other from the very beginning, but as the stress of the crisis that they're involved in reveals different parts of their personalities to one another, they may find a way to make something less of a disaster of their marriage. 

Beyond the obvious relationship aspect of The Painted Veil, it also gives a pretty startling look at how disease was treated at that time, as well as what the British footprint was like in China. I found those parts of the story to really be more interesting than the stuff between Watts and Norton. Other than their dodgy British accents, I though they were fine in their roles. It just would have been nice if events didn't play out exactly as almost anyone could have guessed after the first ten minutes. 

How much you enjoy this period movie will depend directly on how much interest you can put into its fairly typical plot. I thought it was okay; no better and no worse.

review_title: Beautiful adaptation of Somerset Maugham's story.
review_detailed_main:
"The Painted Veil" brings many elements of good story telling in film form to the viewer. The leads of Walter and Kitty, played here by Edward Norton and Naomi Watts are perfect in their parts though I had some reservations about Edward's accent prior to seeing the film. but he brings an authenticity to the part that resonates. His overall sad mien, his intellectual intensity and his surprising flares of passion are riveting.

I got to care what happened to Walter and Kitty over the course of the film. Kitty starts out being a shallow clothes horse, looking to escape from an overpowering ambitious mother, and her character's evolution and growth is the crux of the story.

The scenery is beautiful and distant and the many bit players are magnificent. Supporting roles of Diana Rigg as a reverend mother and Toby Jones as Waddington, a type of consul in the area, are wonderfully played. Toby Jones pulled me into the world he had created for himself in this barren outpost.

The theme of journey runs throughout the film, and is also part of the promotional material, I believe. Suffice to say without spoilers is that Walter and Kitty go very far indeed to bridge the distance between each other.

Marvellous, satisfying film. Both stars are amazingly authentic in these magnificent roles. 8 out of 10.

review_title: Cultural Disconnection Meets Modern Science & Personalised Relationship Drama
Absolutely stunning, powerful film filmed with incredible acting
review_detailed_main: I'm a HUGE fan of Edward Norton and this is unquestionably one of his finest films. The story is deeply moving, the cinematography is just beautiful, and the acting is exquisite! Edward Norton is at perhaps his finest playing a deceptively low-key role that ends up creating so much depth of character that by the end of the film it's almost a gut-shot to realize just how far his character has come. Naomi Watts is just as good and provides a complex character that elicits all kinds of genuine emotions from the viewer: she's flighty and flakey at times, she's sincere and somber, she's flawed and horrible yet has redeeming qualities that make her impossible not to root for. Add in the most delicately balanced screenplay and easily the most visually stunning cinematography of the past 20 years, and you've got the recipe for a 10-star film.

It's quite interesting to see one same movie casts such polarized impressions in the audience. A movie like this needs patience and I understand not everyone was in the right mood to enjoy it, but to my shock, one negative review, which gives 4 out of 10 to it simply because 4 sounds like death in Chinese, is way too mean. I see this movie as not perfect and there's room for improvement, however I admire the passion its cast and crew showed that makes up the missing 1 point and adds up to a perfect 10.

Most negative comments say the painted veil is "long and dull". I agree it is long albeit I didn't feel so at watching, but I won't say it's dull. This movie is very eventful IMHO, where transformation takes place gradually and quietly and can be felt through details, just like how changes happen in our life. Such subtlety keeps me engaged throughout the 2 hours. The painted veil isn't as dramatic as some movies that give the audience a twist every several minutes, and it doesn't unnecessarily prolong "important" events to dramatize itself. The climax is achieved after the audience's emotion has been slowly built up during those transformations, and it ends succinctly, leaving us to think. I like this way of story telling, simple but precise, nothing wasted. What else I like about this movie, such as acting, screenplay, music and etc, has been mentioned so many times. So I won't repeat them again.

Bravo to the team! Thank you for bringing us a wonderful movie!

review_title: It's a bit of a Bouquet-series-book, but it's not bad

Sometimes it's very nice to watch these kind of movies even tough the story itself stays a bit shallow. A kind of old-fashioned movie in the style of The English Patient or Out Of Africa. It lacks a bit of the strength and intensity of those two, but if you liked those you could give The Painted Veil a try. For myself i enjoyed it but i wouldn't consider buying the DVD or watch it for a second time in the near future. A bit of a in-betweener. Could have been real good if they only tried to make it more of an art-house movie you know with a real literally script. But anyway nice try.

review_title: Beautiful and exquisite piece of art!
review_detailed_main:
I had no expectations for this movie but was astonished by the quality of the artwork and the impact it had.

This is an old-fashioned piece of film telling a romantic story among beautiful scenery and with some astounding performances (especially from the always underrated Ed Norton).

The movie doesn't employ any modern gadgets or techniques to entertain the viewer. Yet with ingredients such as great story, leading couple with incredible chemistry and talent and scenery to die for, it delivers and enchants the audience.

You have to wonder why they don't make more movies like this anymore. Why, really?

Bored rich girl Kitty (Naomi Watts) marries shy, overly series microbiologist Walter Fane (Edward Norton), mainly to get away from her parents who disapprove of her irreverent lifestyle. Stunned by his wife's brief affair with the caddish Charlie Townsend (Liev Schreiber), Walter threatens to ruin her reputation by divorcing her, unless she accompanies him into an area of China ravaged by a cholera epidemic. Against this background of hardship and disease they learn to love each other. Maybe for the first time.

Although it sometimes surfs too close to the perilous waters of self parody, I actually rather liked "The Painted Veil". I wasn't at all surprised that it had been filmed before in the 1930's. Except for some pretty graphic scenes of death by cholera, it is exactly the kind of old fashioned Sunday afternoon melodrama that my Mom used to love so much (and probably still does).

Naomi Watts suffers prettily. (Make no mistake, she is gorgeous, even unwashed and sweaty.) Edward Norton tries on an English accent and finds that it fits. (He is almost an alien from a distant civilization in his buttoned up cream suit. It works, as well, showing his isolation from his wife.) Toby Jones essays an old school English diplomat abroad. (Nearly gone native.) Liev Schrieber is a... er... cad. (Sadly without the strokable moustache). Old fashioned, solid film making. Not the kind of thing I would normally see, frankly, but a grown up proper movie, a world away from robots, wizards, green ogres and Bruce Willis in a vest.

Worth a look.

This is a good romance movie but didn't seem like a great one. What really drives this movie is the two leads played by Edward Norton and Naomi Watts. Edward Norton since it's Edward Norton and Naomi Watts because she is just good at these period piece movies. This movie deals with misunderstandings and how we can miss out on true love because sometimes we try to see the negatives more than the positives in people. And how even when we find true love and are together still don't know it. Since we tend to miss or lose the things that are right in front of us. I saw this film well reviewed here, and I could not have been more pleased in my viewing of it. Wow! What a great film! It is a slow and steadily paced human and interpersonal drama. These are very real and human characters and watching the dynamics between them unfold as the plot moves back and forth is like watching a flower unfold. This is a beautiful and haunting film. I didn't know they still made films this rich and good.

First and foremost, this is a pretty good film. Wonderfully nuanced performances by Norton and Watts, and the cinematography is some of the better work I've seen in quite awhile. That said, I found two major faults that really work against it: one, it is difficult to comprehend just how much time passes from one section to the next. Sometimes you find yourself thinking several months have passed when it may have actually only been a couple weeks. The other quibble I have is with the story itself - without giving away any spoilers, I found the plot to have been done so many other times - it is just in another setting. Granted, I despised Titanic for some of the same reasons. The difference is that the storytelling is much better here. Just don't watch this movie expecting anything original.

This is a good film undermined by fussy and therefore muddled direction. The narrative is confused by too many flashbacks and unnecessary flash-forwards. The very competent cast is further undermined by uncertain direction and trite, cliché ridden set pieces. Some of the motivating thrust driving characters to action are unconvincing. Perhaps this is the original author's fault, but the film's script has failed to resolve these important issues. The language of the film is very, very 2006. This is frankly laughable. It would be intolerable to listen to a totally authentic rendering of early twentieth century English, but to allow so many crass twenty first century idioms to litter the script is... crass. The photography is very well achieved even a little too beautiful at times for the situation being portrayed. Overall this is a bit of a disappointment.

This was a simple story about the power of love, and the virtue of leading a morally sound life. By the sound of it, you may think I'm a religious fanatic: quite the contrary. I was raised Catholic, but I 'lost the faith' a long time ago. I believe in God yes, but I believe he works within us, within each individual. He is not some grand, all-knowing being with all the answers to the universe in the palm of his hand. In my mind God is the essence of virtue; humble, and at all times learning new things- so that he may know himself better.

So how in God's name does this relate to the movie? Well, after having seen it, I believe the movie speaks with a touch of God in its voice. This idea is not always financially viable for producers of such movies, but consider the source: with Jean Francois Fonpult, Mark Gill, Naomi Watts and Edward Norton as producers, it makes a lot more sense to me that this movie was made. I have even more respect for them now, being bold enough to fund such a unique and simply developed story.

Moreover the film was beautifully crafted- Stuart Dryburgh's framing and lens mastery were of the best in the business. Alexandre Desplat's score was gorgeous and captivating. Alexandre de Franceschi's editing was superb...a fine balance between art and story. There are no extraneous moments throughout the film- there is no incessant humor to dilute the story, just to fill the cracks. As Norton's character 'Dr.Fane' states: "...I've not been in the habit of answering questions I had no response to." So does this film do its work with graceful and intelligent dialogue: which cuts to the heart of what's at stake for these characters.

Actors: Go see this film. There are no bad performances. Each player knows his or her place, and commits to telling the story with discipline and courage. Ron Nyswaner-well done. Directors: What better way to study structure and fluidity and to see the two become one- in a seemingly effortless manner? John Curran's voice is there, but you only hear it through the respective movie's seamless synchronicity of matter and spirit.

Moviegoers: See this film if you want to be moved in a very profound way. If you like action films, this ain't your cup of tea, but if you're ever ready, this film will quietly wait- it will be around for film connoisseurs of the future to say what a beautiful film it was, and see how it was overlooked? Chances are many will not be ready to see what lies beneath the Painted Veil.

review_title: Making W. Somerset Maugham's Novel Visual
review_detailed_main:
Though some readers who are familiar with the novel, 'The Painted Veil', may have quibbles about the altered sequences and places of action and character emphasis in Ron Nyswaner's screenplay, those disparities pale in comparison to the superb acting and cinematic treatment of Maugham's story about the development of love in the most unlikely situation. John Curran directs his superb cast with fluid movement, allowing the story to unfold in flashbacks in a manner suggestive of the longing and the nightmares of dreams.

Bacteriologist physician Dr. Kane (Edward Norton) is devoted to his work, and part of his work is to quickly marry so that he may proceed with his obsession with his career. In London he is introduced to the reluctant Kitty (Naomi Watts), a lass who continues to look for the perfect love of her life, but is confronted with reality when her father demands she marry. Kitty is not attracted to Dr. Kane but agrees to marry him and soon they are off to China. While in Shanghai (no, not Hong Kong) Kitty is bored until she meets Charlie Townsend (Liev Schreiber) who, though married and a man of public image, sweeps Kitty off her feet. Their affair is discovered by Dr. Kane and he insists that Kitty either follow him to a small village in interior China, a town besieged by cholera, or go public with a divorce. Kitty turns to her lover Charlie who refuses to divorce his society wife and Kitty sadly follows her husband to the sick village.

Once settled in the village the couple is befriended by a fellow British gentleman Waddington (Toby Jones) and while Dr. Kane works devotedly with his patients and his epidemiological efforts to stem the cholera, Kitty finds refuge with a group of nuns who care for the children of the dead. The Mother Superior (Diana Rigg) helps Kitty to adjust and to see the inherent good in her husband, a man who is not only a fine physician but also able to accept the fact that his once disconsolate wife is pregnant, probably as a result of her dalliance with Charlie Townsend. As the couple begin to accept and appreciate each other the disease strikes home and the story ends with evidence of inner growth in everyone involved.

Norton, Watts, Jones, and Rigg are radiant in their understated roles - Norton's English accent is superb. The beauty of the film is due in a large part to the beauty of the landscapes of China, but also in an equal part to the eloquent cinematography of Stuart Dryburgh and the musical score composed by Alexandre Desplat (with a nod of Satie) and played by pianist Lang Lang. The film is as soft in appearance as a painted veil and the mood it creates lingers - even for those who prefer the written novel! Grady Harp

The visuals are effective and artful, we see the peasants dying in the streets, Kitty is at once horrified and outraged that her husband has required she accompany him.

The visuals and soundtrack including Satie and other beautiful flowing scenes as the water and mountains of China are shown, lush and misty. Beautiful scenery in the midst of a cholera epidemic. The contrasts are many.

The end is dramatic yet believable, and she has a son and becomes self-actualized. As she runs into Liev Schreiber in London, she has released that part of her life, he has lost her, and she walks away knowing her life is now complete and peaceful. 10/10

review_title: Teachings of Love, Self, and Salvation
review_detailed_main:
The Painted Veil is more than just a brilliant score, surely. Walter Fane marries Kitty, a spoiled higher class lady whose only rebellion is to marry someone she doesn't give much thought about, just to be away from her mother. Kitty finds another man and thinks she is finally happy, only to be taken aback by the true nature of the man who is unable to leave his wife. Be it a disappointment, or be it self-destruction, she embarks on a journey with Walter to a kingdom far, far away, China, albeit one doomed with a cholera epidemic, with inconceivable consequences. One would think the journey takes them so far away, and yet, in all that despair and too-wild-for-a-British-lady circumstances in Southern China, the real story begins. "Sometimes the greatest journey is the distance between two people." -W. Somerset Maugham.

Walter knows what he needs to do, Kitty thinks he's crazy, Kitty has to follow him, Walter works to save others but destroys himself, Kitty suffers, Kitty thinks, Kitty wants to follow Walter, Kitty becomes Kitty Fane for the first time in a lifetime. It's a painfully real love story, where two people first blindly (yet brilliantly) follow their heart only to find they didn't know any better and yet, embark on a journey together to truly save themselves, and for the most part, each other. It is also a love story that empowers us to want to be better than who we already are, which is truly distinguished through both the narrative originally penned by W. Somerset Maugham and the sometimes chillingly sane adaptation by Ron Nyswaner.

A movie for generations, The Painted Veil will stay a classic for more decades to come. Wonderful cinematography with a backdrop of both England and China in the 1920s; splendid score by Alexandre Desplat that informs his Oscar-worthy achievements; subtle yet emotional performance by Edward Norton and Naomi Watts...there is some life behind every scene to derive and ponder, despite the sometimes gloomy depiction of despair in the epidemic-stricken countryside of Southern China, of course. This is probably the first Edward Norton movie I have seen, even before I caught up with Fight Club. Somerset Maugham's 'The Painted Veil' is a restrained masterpiece of a book, the story of a young woman put through emotional and physical torture as a consequence of (selfishly but naturally) following her own desires, and eventually understanding the need for independence in a world where women were expected to build lives around their choice of man. In this film, all the characters are recreated in a way that reflects their presence in the novel; but nonetheless, the movie falls flat. Key to the book is Kitty's often harrowed internal mental state, which Maugham showcases sympathetically but without asserting that his heroine is in any way morally superior to those around her; in the film, she just glides gracefully through cholera-infested China, superficially special but without the story giving us any real reason for caring for her. Some of the dialogue is clunky (a British doctor describing himself as an 'M.D.', for example), and the added action scenes seem wholly peripheral. Finally, as in 'Madame Bovary', a critical section of the book is the final period, after the death of a key character; but this is shortened and morally simplified in the film. The book is uncannily perceptive in its depiction of all of its characters; this film just passed ineffectually over me.

The Maugham novel gets a fine screen adaptation and it's even improved by the twist in the tale of unhappily married Kitty and Walter.

Walter (Norton) is a serious scientist, perhaps a bit socially awkward, who falls for pretty socialite Kitty (Watts). While Walter wants to get married fast and take his bride to China for some companionship abroad, marriage is the last thing in Kitty's mind, except that she is getting old and her parents aren't too keen about supporting her as an ageing spinster.

Pushed by shame for her condition as soon not sellable anymore on the marriage market and devoid of professional skills, Kitty marries Walter, even if it's clear that they are unsuitable. Once in China, Kitty falls for the superficial charm of expat lothario Townsend.

Walter takes his revenge by dragging Kitty to a cholera-infested area of Southern China. There Kitty embarks on a solitary journey of self-discovery and tries to mend her relationship with Walter. While in the book Walter remains distant and aloof, the decision of making him softer and forgiving adds a layer of tragedy to the plot.

The somber atmosphere of the movie is enhanced by the melancholic soundtrack, which I did not like, but I understand the choice of plunging the story into the unremitting sadness of the human condition.

Not surprisingly this realistic and somber love story was not a box office success, despite the wonderful settings, costumes and performances. Just too grown-up and sophisticated for contemporary audience.

review_title: Painted Veil- Somerset Maugham At it Again ***
review_detailed_main:

Angered when he discovers the affair, Norton wants a divorce but soon "compromises" his feelings by having Watts come with him to a remote area in China undergoing a cholera epidemic. Of course, Schrieber would not divorce his wife for political and social reasons.

The film tells us that through loneliness and frustration, Watts soon finds comfort in working in an orphanage and meets with an understanding nun, well played by Diana Rigg.

It is through this work that Watts finds herself and she and Norton fall back in love. She is pregnant and the film never clearly states who the father is.

With revolution and the epidemic enduring, all seems to be going well with the couple until the cholera hits one of them with tragic consequences.

The film is beautifully realized with some lovely cinematography.

Somerset Maugham in 1925) was amazing as well, but seeing these brilliant actors bring it to life was astonishing. The screenplay was adapted wonderfully and the dialogue was biting and evocative. I only wish that this movie was more recognized at the awards (Oscars, Golden Globes, etc.) earlier on in the year. You must see this movie! I love it!

Quite Possibly, my favorite rental movie of 2008. I missed this film in the actual movies, but I have made up for not seeing it there, but buying a copy and watching it about 45 times since.

Naomi Watts is just perfect in this tale of woe, love lost, love forgotten and love never to be? Edward Norton is also perfect just being himself in this complicated love story taking place in the Far East!

i have since read some of the other comments about the film, please I beg of you, see it again-the original book expresses the characters to be from the 1920's ( The Norton character was even more hum drum in the original book, and Naomi's character was a Hotsie totsie type ( so they actually made the movie better than the book:) people don't realize how life was back then-this was true to force for people of that time. give it another chance, it really is a great movie.

review_title: Unsentimental novel turned into a very emotional film.
Watts and Norton chemistry and individual performances are central to the film's emotional impact, making it a compelling drama
review_detailed_main:
In this movie both Edward Norton and Naomi Watts deliver captivating performances. Norton's portrayal of Dr. Walter Fane is marked by a subtle intensity, capturing his character's internal struggle and complex emotions. Watts, on the other hand, brings a nuanced depth to Kitty Fane, effectively conveying her transformation from a superficial socialite to a deeply introspective individual. Their chemistry and individual performances are central to the film's emotional impact, making it a compelling drama.

Edward Norton and Naomi Watts both deliver remarkable performances in "The Painted Veil." Norton excels in portraying Dr. Walter Fane with a remarkable blend of restraint and emotional depth. His ability to convey internal conflict and a brooding sense of duty adds layers to his character, making Walter's journey from a distant, clinical figure to someone grappling with profound personal changes both believable and compelling.

Naomi Watts, meanwhile, is equally impressive as Kitty Fane. Her performance captures the complexity of Kitty's evolution, from a superficial and self-centered woman to someone who undergoes a genuine transformation and finds deeper meaning in her life. Watts brings a poignant vulnerability to the role, showcasing Kitty's growth and the internal struggles she faces as she contends with her own shortcomings and her evolving relationship with Walter.

Together, Norton and Watts create a powerful dynamic that drives the emotional core of the film. Their interactions are charged with authenticity, and their performances are instrumental in conveying the film's themes of redemption, forgiveness, and the search for personal growth. Their strong portrayals elevate the story, making "The Painted Veil" a moving and memorable cinematic experience.

review_title: "Sometimes the greatest journey is the distance between two people"

review_detailed_main:
All the parts are here... location, style, source material, acting talent... but it's all wasted on this listless, dreary soap.

But that's not the worst part. Edward Norton is hopelessly miscast and his attention to perfecting the monotonous British accent (which is quite good) is at the expense of delivering a character worth rooting for. It's a stilted, wooden act, better suited to theatre that lacks charisma. So even when he's a do-gooder saving the world, we don't really care.

The affair, too, is a lifeless physical connection between two bored people that lacks credibility. She seems to have gone off the deep end after a one night stand, which is ridiculous.

All in all, it's tedious and dull.

review_title: A Magnificent Work of Cinematic Art -- well told story
review_detailed_main: I have never before commented on a film on this site but this one commands that I do. This film is exceptional -- the story and the characters were beautifully developed -- and the settings of the rugged Chinese mountain landscape are stunning. Often while watching films, even those I enjoy, I check my watch to see if 'we are half way through' -- with TPV, no way, I was not ready for it to end. I admire the risk taken by both of the lead actors to produce this great movie. I hope that it gains more attention. I will talk it up as much as possible. I love this movie! It's story, characters, scenery, actors (Naomi Watts and Edward Norton). Beautiful. I've seen it many times, and always discover new details. Highly recommend.

review_detailed_main: We watch a movie almost every night. Seldom is an evening so rich and fulfilling as this evening. This film is EVERYTHING the movies should be. Romance.Drama.Historical setting. Exotic locations. Powerful performances. Superb cinematography. Nor is there any excess. Not in the sex scenes. Not in the acting. Not in the photography which captures the mood of both the place and time in wonderful pastel hues, intriguing composition and original angles. But the camera never steals the show as sometimes happens. Everyone is great but Toby Jones is especially effective as the dissolute ex-pat Waddington. And the ending... Well, it's the sort of thing that triggers lively discussion at breakfast the next morning.

review_title: Exquisite Scenery, well acted. Has slow moments, but definitely worth the 'End of the British Empire' moods
review_detailed_main:
Watched this last night on Netflix. At first, was annoyed by Naomi Watt's heavy Australian accent bleeding through her British character's, along with Ed Norton's very weak accent.
