review_title: Great tale of infidelity, revenge and love.
review_detailed_main:
I enjoyed this film and thought both Watts' and Norton's performances were excellent - particularly impressed with Norton. His British accent was impeccable, to the point that I could not tell the difference. He carried off the accent so easily it surprised me. The film is a little slow and drawn-out, so if you don't like that kind of thing then I would give this a miss if I were you.

Watching the 2 main characters slowly fall in love under the most difficult and tragic of circumstances, was a pleasure. I have never read the novel, but taking the film purely on its own basis, I give it a 9/10. It is a true love story, and wholly believable.

The downside to the film, and the reason I did not give it a 10, is it is rather long-winded. I became a little bored half way through. Also, I did not like Liev Schreiber in it. I felt he was miscast and his half-hearted attempt at a British accent I found annoying. Especially as both Norton and Watts did such a good job with theirs. But overall, it is an excellent film, if you are into that kind of thing.

Imagine being in a foreign land, knowing no one but your spouse who hates you. This is exactly what Kitty Fane (Watts) goes through when her husband decides to drag them both into a cholera epidemic in imperialist China. In "The Painted Veil", Kitty is a vivacious young woman living in the 1920's England when she agrees to marry the shy, introverted Dr. Walter Fane (Norton) in order to escape her nagging mother. While Walter is desperately in love with her, Kitty is merely indifferent to him. She and her new husband move to Shanghai, China where Walter works a bacteriologist. Kitty soon finds herself falling for the English Vice Consul, Charles Townsend (Liev Schreiber). The two soon begin a secret affair. When Walter finds out, he gives Kitty a choice: either accompany him to a small town that is suffering from a cholera epidemic or he will divorce her, creating a huge scandal. As they work through the problems they face due to the cholera, they also learn to appreciate each other.

This amazing motion picture, based on the novel by W. Somerset Maugham, truly captures what China would have been like at the time the movie takes place and what the English who were living there would have gone through. The main reason why the country is portrayed so realistically is because Warner Independents and Yari Groups, the two companies in charge of the film, collaborated with a Chinese film company to help improve scripts and make it as accurate as possible. The music also adds to the authenticity as it's a mixture of classical European music as well as Chinese-based sounds. The costumes are also accurately portrayed. None of the costumes are over done or out of place for the story. Norton and Watts do a wonderful job of portraying their character's emotions and making them seem like real human beings.

The one change that I would make to this spectacular movie would be to vary the camera angles somewhat. The shots are almost always straight on and it would add much more variety to the movie as a whole if there were varied shots. Besides that, this is a film that I would recommend to anyone, especially if you are in the mood for a period flick. I would give the movie four out of five stars. "The Painted Veil" is a movie that I've seen many times but each time it brings something new to my attention.

review_title: It was silly of us to look for qualities in each other that we never had.
review_detailed_main:
How can a man be so selfless and possessive at the same time? Edward Norton's character, Dr. Walter Fane, is an ideal man of every women. Not only a faithful and loving husband, his selfless desire to help others is unbelievable. It's sad that it happens in real life, and most of them weren't given enough recognition. Edward Norton is so soft and his voice is so tiny and gentle, that helped the audience immensely to empathize with him. 2nd, Naomi Watts is so beautiful. Like how is that even allowed?? I felt for her, her eyes are so emotional, and you could actually feel for her sufferance, towards redemption.

The thing that men do, the silent treatment, whenever you commit a mistake, is painstakingly hurtful. I'm just experimenting words here, aren't I? What I meant to say is that we see Dr. Walter Frane as a selfless, and loyal husband who would never hurt his wife. Yet he punished her, in a very deliberate manner without physically hurting her. He wanted her to own up to her mistakes herself, to feel the remorse by herself.

This one is definitely worth watching. Very creative dialogue, making it easy for a foreigner to empathize even though it's set in a different era. Great cinematography, and fantastic score! Alexandre Desplat never disappoints.

review_title: Stunningly photographed, haunting story, wish more could see it
review_detailed_main: The Painted Veil is one of the best pictures of the year, but sadly, it may not get the audience that it deserves. It features two strong performances from Naomi Watts and Edward Norton, who also produced the movie, giving their participation in it extra meaning. Norton gives a beautifully crafted depiction of Walter, a doctor who is by turns cruel, intent, vulnerable and passionate. Watts is excellent as always in her role as a spoiled socialite completely unsuited for a journey to rural China, but who matures as the movie progresses. Both these performances are textbook examples of how to present a character. The music and clothes, not to mention the stunning photography, give it the sense of a David Lean or Merchant-Ivory production, yet it has far more honesty. The movie will resonate with people who have traveled to China or who are interested in the role of English missionaries (for Walter is something of a missionary) during the pre-WWII era. Moviegoers who enjoyed The Motorcycle Diaries, who liked Watts in 21 Grams and who appreciate the details of film-making should see this movie.

review_title: Cholera rips through the country while deceit rips apart their marriage.
"Sometimes the greatest journey is the distance between two people"

review_detailed_main:
I saw this tonight at a free sneak preview screening. Watching this was pure joy. The characters were sublime, the locations just gorgeous, a tragic love story of the kind that simply isn't written anymore. When the last scene faded away, the entire theater sat in silence for several minutes, no one wanting to get up and disturb the magic we were a part of.

The story begins with Kitty, a young British girl of a marrying age, whose parents are eager for her to leave the nest. She has idealized notions of marriage, and wants to remain single until she finds true love.

Dr. Walter Fain, a micro-biologist studying epidemics in Shanghai, "sees her from across a crowded room" and immediately takes a liking to her. He is very quiet and shy, but after several walkabouts with Kitty, proposes to her. Kitty is shocked, as she is too self-absorbed to have noticed Dr. Fain's pining.

Kitty's parents give her an ultimatum: Marry, or move out and support yourself. Walter promises to do anything it takes to make her happy, so she accepts his proposal. They move to China and all is well for a short time, until Kitty meets dashing, married Charlie. Charlie is everything Dr. Fain is not and Kitty quickly falls in love with him and begins a torrid affair.

Naturally, Walter becomes suspicious and when his fears are confirmed, he exacts revenge by transferring to a very rural and remote part of China that is facing the worst cholera outbreak ever seen. He forces Kitty to accompany him, but continues to punish her by ignoring her, avoiding her and leaving her entirely alone while he works to contain the spread of the epidemic. Will the disdain Kitty and Dr. Fain have for one another overrule their relationship?

review_title: Brilliant story..... subtly written and well performed
review_detailed_main:
Now that is called a movie. Wonderful chemistry! So apparent in today's scenario and yet been depicted in a subtle manner.

Strange how Naomi Watts wanted a guy who would sweep her off her feet, ends up with Edward Norton who loves her beyond limit and marries her (although she doesn't love him and does that in order to escape her mundane family life). Pretty soon he discovers his wife cheating on him falling for Liev Schreiber behind his back. She gets involved with Liev Schreiber although when the topic for a divorce is raised she gets baffled by an agreement of Edward after Liev flatly rejects her. However she follows Edward to a camp in China (as his agreement demanded) where the disease of Cholera was widespread like an epidemic. Edward being a doctor tries to help the people while she realizes how stupid she had been to betray a guy like Edward. She realizes her mistake and jumps in to assist him in every possible way.

The movie is wonderfully directed which apparently involved a great storyline. The flick is a worth watch as it toys with human emotions and elucidates both sides of the coin in a subtle manner. You have to sympathize with Norton and Watts sometimes although you would want everything to end happily.

The credit entirely goes to Edward Norton and Naomi Watts because of their joint venture and the magic that they created together. Although the director John Curran did some great directing here the writer W. Somerset Maugham's novel shouldn't be forgotten which deserves more kudos than anything else. Cinematography was brilliant. The story was well portrayed with an apt screenplay.
I have watched this movie Simple plot, repeated and Boring Not suitable for family or teens.

Excellent acting. Great choice of actors. Edward Norton and Naomi Watts are definitely the right choice for the roles. Anthony Wong is one of the best actors in Hong Kong. All of them have great performance in the film. The scenes are beautiful, and the movie reflects the anti-foreign sentiment of that time in China accurately. Only one thing to criticize: the story took place somewhere along the Yangze River, which is in the central part of China. However, some of the extras spoke Cantonese, which is the language spoken in southern part of China, including Hong Kong. Having the wrong type of dialect being spoken in the movie may take away some of its authenticity. {Just found out the film was actually shot in Guilin, which is in the southern part of China. That's why.}

My 18-yr-old son and I went to see this film yesterday and we loved it. Edward Norton is, as usual, magnificent. (I still think he should have won the Best Actor Academy Award for American History X back in 1996.) In the Painted Veil -- the story and characters are gripping. Great character development, screenplay, unforgettable cinematography, with understated (and yet terribly moving) performances by all the major players -- seriously. It was wonderful! I'm hoping to see (at least) a Best Picture nomination, Best Actor, and Best Actress, and Best Supporting Actor for Toby Jones. I believe it's one to be seen on the big screen -- don't wait for the DVD.

Probably one of the most stylish movies in the past few years. I would say it is a 100% of what Maugham's novel should look like on screen. The colors, the scenery, the mood, the slight touch of old style, the accent gave me the feeling that I am actually inside a book, inside this story, and not only sitting in front of a bright screen chewing Haribos from Candy King. In fact, I forgot all about my Haribos after the first 15 minutes of the movie. What is one of the best achievements of this movie is the successful balance on the thin line between humorous and tragic. Good acting, too. I was 100% on Norton's character's side, although he obviously appears to be a negative personage for his actions towards his wife. What I liked even more is that there are no "good" or "bad" characters in this movie, and they all seem quite human and real. All in all I consider this movie worth watching. In a relaxed unhurried mood though.

review_title: Norton & Watts + the most beautiful soundtrack
review_detailed_main:
Edward Norton & Naomi Watts are amazing actors, and even if you dislike the story, you will love their performances. They have screen chemistry and, apparently, Edward Norton even personally asked Naomi Watts to join the movie production.

Two wonderful characters, played by great professionals, accompanied by the most beautiful soundtrack I have ever heard!

Even to this day, I still remember it as unique and beautifully haunting.

The movie seemed almost like a fever dream, and I was never once bored.

A classic for me - especially because of the great selection of classical music and top cast in it.

review_title: Slow endurance in the heart of China of a failed marriage with cholera.
review_detailed_main:
To watch this film after having seen the Greta Garbo version of 1934 is a challenge indeed. They are both excellent but at the same time each other's contraries. This version is truer to Somerset Maugham, while the Garbo version is so much more efficient and dramatic. Naomi Watts and Edward Norton are bleak and almost insipid in their performances in comparison with the passions of Garbo, Herbert Marshall and George Brent. The 1934 film is also much more interesting in its rendering of the Chinese reality of those days. Compare for instance the couple's visit to the Chinese opera. In 1934 it's a phantasmagoria of festivities, while here it's just one actress miaowing.

On the other hand, this version is so much more beautiful. The Chinese landscape is intoxicating in its beauty, and Alexander Desplat's music, always enchanting, casts a soft spell of sweetness over the film in a sad mood of inevitability. Edward Norton's role is a difficult one, it is never sympathetic, and Naomi Watts does not cut a very sympathetic figure either, while Greta Garbo still shines the more after 80 years. The tempo is slow, you are bound to yawn at times and maybe even fall asleep to the soft dullness, while the 1934 film keeps you wide awake all through indeed. On the other hand, this film does not abandon Somerset Maugham but walks the line all the way.

review_title: Can Filmmakers Leave Anything To The Imagination?
review_detailed_main:
I gather this film is geared to people who are fairly sophisticated, and educated. For example, Baltimore is a fairly large city, and only one small theater is currently showing this movie! So I find it hard to believe the filmmakers, in their infinite wisdom, needed to show extremely graphic images of people dying of Cholera, not to mention grotesque scenes of corpses, to the very people who already have a pretty good idea about what dying from Cholera is all about.

As a result of being caught off guard by these rather gruesome images, I literally lost my dinner after the movie was over. Where do I send the bill? Can anything be left to the imagination, anymore? Why are so many films these days so morbid? Is the movie going public becoming so desensitized that nothing is shocking? Are American filmmakers helping to turn us into a nation of mindless voyeurs? If I wanted, or needed, to learn more about Cholera, all I have to do is hop on the Internet, or God-forbid, pick-up a book, and read. I didn't need to spend my hard earned money to be nauseated!

All I can say is thank God for the man who invented the purification process for public drinking water - he should be nominated for sainthood! And the next time you gripe about your Government spending money on foreign aid in very poor countries, keep this movie in mind! For Cholera still kills plenty of people in the developing world, each, and every day - because a huge segment of the human race still does not have access to safe drinking water!

review_title: A worthy film, more for girls than guys
review_detailed_main: I went to see this film with my girlfriend. We both liked it, but she left crying and told me that she probably enjoyed it more than I. First off, I never saw Edward Norton in a bad film and the Painted Vail is no exception. The film starts off rather slow, but remains interesting throughout. The script is entirely realistic, believable, and cleverly written as well as masterfully executed. The acting and directing are top notch. Its a film mainly about relationships and the imperfections in each of us. There are many issues explored in this film and some of them relate to our present world situation. Its essentially a tragedy, but its beauty and meaning surpass any depressive aspect to move us to recognize what is best within each of us.

review_title: One of the Year's Best --- A Naomi Watts Comeback?
review_detailed_main:
In 2006 and 2007, the two poorest years in terms of quality films, it doesn't take a lot for a film to be outstanding; but PAINTED VEIL offers audiences quite a package.

First you have an outstanding story based on a fine novel: Broken love and how it can motivate a person into unpredictable paths, such as fighting a cholera epidemic in a remote village in China. Second, the on location filming in China and the brilliant re-creation of the 1925 Old China --- pretty much destroyed during the 1950's when Chinese villagers were rounded up by the Red Guard and placed into forced labor camps, families destroyed, etc. Third, the excellent performances by Edward Norton and Naomi Watts.

Edward Norton is always an asset to a movie, one of my favorite current stars; but Naomi Watts deserves a few special comments: First, she'll be compared to Greta Garbo in the original. I say there is no comparison. Sorry, Grandpops, but Greta was nothing to look at and her acting was flat (and overrated). Naomi Watts, a girl of today, never fails to play an authentic 1925 woman --- with all the limitations they had in those times. I never thought Miss Watts could overcome the silly and awful role Peter Jackson (today's worst film director)saddled her with in his dreadful gorilla "remake." Jackson ought to be prosecuted in court for the damage he inflicted on Miss Watts, as well as the mess he made (for $150 million) of a great American classic (King Kong). The jury is still out on her career recovery, as this fine film is still unproven at the box office.

Movies aimed at adults (and free of special effects excess, men wearing capes or having over-sized white wings, toilet humor) have become so few that Hollywood ought not expect adults to return to movie theaters just because an occasional fine film is mixed in with the abundance of trash.

The most tragic thing about this film is that it is bursting with potential but does not allow it release, almost as though its creators in their method of telling story and recalling past through melancholic melody and lingered moments of pause were afraid of tearing the canvas of frailty and beauty they had envisioned - and very much successfully realized, to much deserved credit. So though this work of art could have been so much more it nevertheless succeeds in becoming and something unique in its beauty and altogether something else entirely, and despite its flawed ending merits no less than the score given it here. A film singular in recent times in its beauty.

i was very happily surprised to see a character driven drama with such wonderful cinematography! The thematic devices used are subtle, yet incredibly effective... it was really refreshing to view a film where things were left to the imagination and not fully explained.

Ed Norton (whos fantastic as usual) and a stellar performance by Naomi Watts really made this movie a fantastic alternative to the mindless CGI action films that plague the cinema today.

The Painted Veil is a great throwback and reminder to how more movies should be made, and by far the best movie i've seen in a very, very long time

10/10 A greatly under-rated and unappreciated work of art.

This is an earnest, old-fashioned movie about love, marriage, sin and redemption, with an exotic setting; it's not on an epic David Lean scale, but the production is big enough to provide a sense of adventure and escape. So what went wrong?

Pity the poor director, who was stuck with two lead actors who also happened to be the producers...so they could not be fired (or sent back for intensive voice classes). Why are so many Brit actors able to deliver convincing, nuanced American accents, but not vice versa? Edward Norton does not have a particularly memorable or resonant voice to start with, and his lame attempt at sounding British constrains his tinny voice even more. Naomi Watts does slightly better, but over the duration of a 2-hour film, her insipid accent, too, begins to get on your nerves. And let's not even talk about Liev Schreiber; fortunately, he's not in the film very long.

(Diana Rigg must also deliver a phony accent, this one French. It, too, is unconvincing, but again, hers is a small role.)

An actor's voice is one of his or her most powerful tools. By forcing themselves into roles in which their voices are constrained and weakened, Watts and Norton simply cannot do justice to their parts. Imagine this movie with, say, Ralph Fiennes or Colin Firth in the lead, and imagine the difference it would make with the delivery of every line...like night and day! Ultimately, it's the performances of the two producers that kill this movie.

I saw this with my girlfriend in the only theater that is showing it in Vancouver... I voted 8/10 as I think it is great, but there are room for improvements.

First of all Edward Norton and Naomi Watts did an amazing job at their roles. I am more and more convinced that I should track down and watch all films with Naomi Watts in it now. Edward is his own excellent self as usual.

The characters are very well done, the background, the story and the main plot lines are all excellent. Even the Chinese village (to me anyways) appears very authentic. So what happened to my rating? What I thought the movie was trying to do - i.e. the message, the moral of story, the meaning of the feature, was somehow average in its delivery. Maybe it's the screenplay, or directing. Like the title says, The Painted Veil has a very simple and clear message and it is very repeatedly said in many ways throughout the film, but somehow they managed to be separate from each other, and it did not build up, the momentum wasn't there. The climactic moments were un-climactic to the movie's central theme. And thus at the end, it did not leave me with a strong impression or a take-home message. With the death of Walter, it felt more like a documentary film than otherwise. It could be just that I was hard to impress.

review_title: A strong story highlighted by two great performances.
review_detailed_main: A phenomenal story based around very authentic characters caught in the midst of a terrible disaster. It's a very sweeping tale of unrequited love turned into a very deep hatred. While the story is magnificent, the film really shines in the two lead performances. Norton's extreme nuance and awkwardly professional prose makes for one of the best performances in recent memory. A shining work certainly robbed of much needed award recognition. Naomi Watts is equally powerful. A beautiful structure shifted from utter selfishness into deep empathy and selflessness by the end of the picture. The transition of their love is very engaging as it progresses from a resent, to utter hatred, to actual sympathy and a very real love by the time it's too late. The actual love scene is one of the most passionate and romantic in recent years. Norton's final scene absolutely broke my heart in two.

I will confess right off the first time I tried watching this I gave up after 20 minutes. I decided later on that I would have missed many slow moving flicks that aren't particularly good in places, but as a whole. This is not a flick for someone with a short attention span, ie, under 18. But for those of us who have grown with age, this is right up your alley. This is one of those flicks that shows you the way love really is. Not all the godforsaken happy ending crap that just about everyone loves, but is not in the least bit realistic for 99% of the world. I won't give anything away except to say it's beautifully shot, the acting is excellent, and yes it moves slow but in the most excellent of ways.

While this is set in China and touches on some political issues, it doesn't get swept away by it luckily which would have turned this film into an anti communist type of film praising the westerners for interfering. review_title: Imperfect People Learning from their Mistakes
review_detailed_main:
I watched The Painted Veil on the evening of Mother's Day and thought, as I sat to write this piece, that this movie would have certainly appealed to my mother. In fact it would appeal to most mothers or anyone who enjoys a good old fashioned melodrama.

The story has been told and told again. A shallow woman marries a man to escape the clutches of her family. They travel to China circa 1925 where he conducts research on bacteria. She has no interest in his work and almost as little in him. He is, to say mildly, less than outgoing in his relations with his wife. She falls into an affair with the local lady's man and is given the choice of receiving a messy divorce or traveling with her husband to the Chinese outback where he is going to help stem an outbreak of cholera. The wife finds that her lover has feet of clay and will not leave his wife, so she regrettably accompanies her husband. Events occur in this remote region which change the lives of this unhappy couple. I told you it was melodrama! Its good direction, professional acting, great production values, and incredible scenery that make this version of The Painted Veil so appealing.

Naomi Watts plays the wife. She does an admirable job at showing us a shallow young woman who matures into a person of value. In the 1934 film, Greta Garbo played the roll. I would have thought that someone such as Bette Davis would have done a good job at this part ala Jezebel.

The distant husband is played by Edward Norton who shows us a man whose emotions are slowly drawn from an inner self to develop into a full grown passion for both his work and his wife.

With just the right amount of sexuality, humor, and bad-boyishness, Liev Schreiber plays the lover.

Character actor Toby Jones who was so excellent as Truman Capote in Infamous plays the local government official who has long since succumbed to the exotic charms of China - no British superiority here.

Finally, those of us who lusted after Emmy Peel, get to see Diana Rigg as the Mother Superior of the local orphanage and clinic. Yes, she's old and wrinkled, but damn, she still looks good.

Take this tale of imperfect people who learn from their mistakes, add a backdrop of some of the most beautiful scenes of nature imaginable, and mix with talented acting and you get a great "guilty pleasure" movie for a Sunday evening.

The Painted Veil presents us with a remarkable combination of actors, setting and drama. The characters of Edward Norton and Naomi Watts play the simplest possible roles they could have had - a spoiled princess and a doctor living in a bubble - but only their remarkable skill as actors could give these characters so much life. From the start, the grandiose landscape of China and the first few moments of the movie guarantee that this is going to be quite a different piece of cinema. Unusual, confusing, terrifying even, it engulfs us as we are thrown into the lives of two people that grow to love each other and learn the painful truth about the world around us.

And although this movie is really, quite excellent, I was still left slightly unsatisfied with certain moments in it. The portrayal of early 20th century China is somehow incomplete. The few moments shown and few pieces of information given are not enough to make the viewer realize the morbid feeling of impending doom and chaos that was quite common in that period. Some scenes left me with unanswered questions, others left me wondering why they even occurred. And most of all, there was a certain lack of time perception; it was quite difficult to say how long has passed between the scenes and often what felt only like days, would later turn out to be months in the movie. This problem with continuity of the plot though probably unintentional, has however made a movie even more enjoyable as we as viewers share a certain sense of confusion and almost feel lost in translation as to what exactly is going on.

Overall, this is a great movie staring two of my most favorite actors and although they are not going to get Oscar for any of the performance in it, they still did an incredible job. 9/10

review_title: Ironic and faintly absurd, yet heart-wrenching all the same

review_detailed_main:
A visually stunning film, focussing on a troubled but passionate relationship in the rapidly changing China of the 1920s, The Painted Veil is a beautifully crafted piece of cinema.

Edward Norton and Naomi Watts are both magnificent, with Norton demonstrating a mastery of his clipped British accent and Watts playing his spoiled but complex wife to perfection. They really have an excellent chemistry in the film that is thoroughly believable and keeps you completely invested to the end. Stellar support comes in the form of Toby Jones and Diana Rigg, both utter chameleons of their trade and great fun here, not forgetting Liev Schreiber's memorable role as the charming cad of the piece.

A sophisticated and beautiful look at what love should mean...this is romantic cinema at its finest!

Everybody says it, and everyone likes hearing the word, but what does "love" really mean?

One cynic said: "Love is just a ploy, devised by the gods to continue the species..." Surely, not all of us share the sentiment of this hater. Most of us would rather intoxicate ourselves with the effervescent words of the great sages of love... this is why as high-school students, naive and idealistic, WE ALL loved Shakespeare...

"Let me not the marriage of true minds, admit impediments, Love is not Love. Which alters when it alteration finds..."

To some, Shakespeare was a blind optimist, but to many, he was the man, the real deal.... Preaching a kind of romantic love that does not alter when everything else does. A love that does not falter in the face of chaos and fuss...

Walter (Ed Norton) and Kitty (Naomi Watts) do not have this kind of love.

Set in the 1920's, Walter is a bacteriologist more enamored with books and diseases than anything else in his uncomplicated life, but when he encounters the beautiful Kitty, he falls in love and proposes marriage.

Kitty, despite her obvious lack of feelings for Walter accepts the proposal for selfish reasons. She wanted to get married ahead of her younger sister and longed for freedom from her pushy parents.

The couple relocated to the British Colony of Hong Kong. Here, Walter continues his research as Kitty becomes more and more restless. Kitty then meets a dashing diplomat named Charlie Townsend and starts an affair with the married man. Walter found out about this and threatened to divorce the unregretful kitty and make a scandal out of it. Fearing the scandal would ruin Charlie, she begs Walter for a quiet proceeding.

Walter agrees, on one condition. - That Kitty asks Charlie to divorce his wife and marry her. If Charlie refuses, Kitty will accompany Walter and (obviously as punishment) must live deep in a cholera-ravished province in mainland China.

Of course Charlie refused, and Kitty, left without a choice, must live with a husband she doesn't even care about, in the middle of an epidemic, and without the comforts of the life she used to live.

***** A painted veil, based on the classic novel by Somerset Maugham, is a one of a kind romance movie. A story where two flawed, hardly likable characters learn the true meaning of love. Love that is not borne of passion, but of forgiveness and 2nd chances.

Part of what makes this movie so good is how it makes the viewer an accomplice, we care for the characters genuinely and almost will them to be together. We become catalysts with our intentions and our hopes.

Loveless though as they may seem, they do not fight, something worse has happened to them-- they have settled into a kind of cold but respectful indifference towards one another. Never knowing what the other is thinking, never saying the things that should be heard, not because they can't or would rather not, but because it plainly doesn't matter anymore. This void, to me, is the abyss of any relationship.

Yet we have this eerie notion that somehow, for some cosmic reason, they are destined to be together. You see, Kitty and Walter do not necessarily subscribe to the Shakepearian platitudes. They are humans, and they're proud of it. Proud in the that they do not find fault in making mistakes, because there's no fault in being imperfect, fault lies in the inability to forgive AND the inability to learn.

Edward Norton and Naomi Watts star in a romantic movie that feels like a Merchant/Ivory production. Norton plays a doctor who is not very comfortable around people and falls in love with a young socialite, Kitty, played by Watts. Despite not being very keen, Kitty marries the doctor due to family pressure, and they move to Shanghai to start their life together. However, in the big city, Kitty finds comfort in the arms of another man. When the doctor learns about her affair, he takes them to a small village that is struggling with cholera. It is here that both characters experience a significant change in themselves.

The on-screen chemistry between Norton and Watts is evident right from the start and only gets stronger as the story progresses. John Curran has skillfully captured the beauty of China on film, while allowing the actors to carry the story. The movie is based on W. Somerset Maugham's novel and is a romantic and artistic experience from start to finish.

The painted veil refers to life, from a Shelley sonnet. Being a movie adaptation of a book by W. Somerset Maugham, it couldn't have been really bad. And being with Edward Norton and foxy Naomi Watts, it couldn't have had bad acting. I mean... he would have been motivated :)

Anyway, this is the type of slow movie that is worth it, at least as romantic movies go. It's the story of an estranged couple finding love in remote China of 1920, during a cholera epidemic. The movie is quite long and may bore people, although I didn't feel bored at all. It presents the shallowness of the British high society of the time, the life of Hong Kong Chinese during the British occupation, the subtle and insidious way in which Catholic orphanages spread their religion, it shows beautiful scenery, but most of all, it shows how you can live by stupid society rules and not see the good things that are right next to you.

There is an earlier adaptation of the book with Greta Garbo in 1934, but I don't intend to watch and make the comparison.

The film is worth seeing in slow, romantic nights. It is not a romantic comedy, if that's what you are looking for. It's deep and dramatic. I mean, it came from a book... :)
